articles.headline: Health’s Gain May Be Army’s Loss
articles.snippet: Call it the law of unintended consequences. When you fix one thing, it messes up other things.
articles.abstract: Call it the law of unintended consequences. When you fix one thing, it messes up other things.
articles.lead_paragraph: Call it the law of unintended consequences. When you fix one thing, it messes up other things.

articles.headline: As Oil Prices Soar, Restaurant Grease Thefts Rise
articles.snippet: The value of processed fryer oil has increased, and there have been reports of thefts in multiple states.
articles.abstract: The value of processed fryer oil has increased, and there have been reports of thefts in multiple states.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bandit pulled his truck to the back of a Burger King in Northern California one afternoon last month armed with a hose and a tank. After rummaging around assorted restaurant rubbish, he dunked a tube into a smelly storage bin and, the police said, vacuumed out about 300 gallons of grease.

articles.headline: Charges of Insider Trading for a Wall Street Luminary
articles.snippet: A retired professor at St. John’s University is accused of passing inside information about a multibillion-dollar corporate takeover to a professor at Pace University.
articles.abstract: A retired professor at St. John’s University is accused of passing inside information about a multibillion-dollar corporate takeover to a professor at Pace University.
articles.lead_paragraph: John F. Marshall spent decades teaching at business schools and watching his students parlay his lessons into fortunes on Wall Street. But when he and another professor reached for some of those riches themselves, events took a startling turn, the authorities say.

articles.headline: Mounting Costs Slow the Push for Clean Coal
articles.snippet: Despite support, plans to take the carbon dioxide that spews from coal-burning power plants and pump it back into the ground have hit roadblocks.
articles.abstract: Despite support, plans to take the carbon dioxide that spews from coal-burning power plants and pump it back into the ground have hit roadblocks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For years, scientists have had a straightforward idea for taming global warming. They want to take the carbon dioxide that spews from coal-burning power plants and pump it back into the ground.

articles.headline: Irate Europeans Protest the Soaring Price of Gasoline
articles.snippet: European governments, already under pressure from slowing economic growth and falling tax revenue, are concerned that anger over higher gas prices could grow.
articles.abstract: European governments, already under pressure from slowing economic growth and falling tax revenue, are concerned that anger over higher gas prices could grow.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  Marie Schneberger has always been thrifty about gasoline. The high price of filling up made it prohibitively expensive for Ms. Schneberger, a middle-income airline employee, to own anything bigger than a Fiat subcompact.

articles.headline: U.S. Withdraws Fulbright Grants to Gaza
articles.snippet: The State Department withdrew the grants to Palestinian students because Israel denied them permission to leave.
articles.abstract: The State Department withdrew the grants to Palestinian students because Israel denied them permission to leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA  The American State Department has withdrawn all Fulbright grants to Palestinian students in Gaza hoping to pursue advanced degrees at American institutions this fall because Israel has not granted them permission to leave.

articles.headline: Lose Homes, Pay More Tax
articles.snippet: Some of the biggest losers in the real estate slump are not purchasers of mansions they could not afford. They are buyers of second homes who are sitting on a tax time bomb.
articles.abstract: Some of the biggest losers in the real estate slump are not purchasers of mansions they could not afford. They are buyers of second homes who are sitting on a tax time bomb.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the biggest losers in the real estate slump are not purchasers of mansions they could not afford. They are buyers of second homes  or third ones, for that matter  who are sitting on a tax time bomb.

articles.headline: Taste of Senate Set Capt. McCain on a New Path
articles.snippet: In John McCain’s quick transition from prisoner of war to politician, a turning point was the year 1981, when he turned down an admiral’s star to make a run for Congress.
articles.abstract: In John McCain’s quick transition from prisoner of war to politician, a turning point was the year 1981, when he turned down an admiral’s star to make a run for Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  At a meeting in his Pentagon office in early 1981, Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman told Capt. John S. McCain III that he was about to attain his life ambition: becoming an admiral.

articles.headline: Food Report Criticizes Biofuel Policies
articles.snippet: Agriculture Secretary Edward T. Schafer is preparing for criticism over American biofuels policy when he meets with world leaders to discuss the global food crisis next week.
articles.abstract: Agriculture Secretary Edward T. Schafer is preparing for criticism over American biofuels policy when he meets with world leaders to discuss the global food crisis next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Agriculture Secretary Edward T. Schafer is preparing to walk into a buzzsaw of criticism over American biofuels policy when he meets with world leaders to discuss the global food crisis next week.

articles.headline: Merger Talks Appear Over for 2 Airlines
articles.snippet: United Airlines told US Airways that it had decided not to continue talks on a possible merger, people with direct knowledge of the situation said.
articles.abstract: United Airlines told US Airways that it had decided not to continue talks on a possible merger, people with direct knowledge of the situation said.
articles.lead_paragraph: United Airlines told US Airways on Thursday that it had decided not to continue talks on a possible merger, people with direct knowledge of the situation said.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Andrew Ross Sorkin
